Content:
## Overview
 Plant galls are abnormal outgrowths of plant tissues, similar to benign tumors or warts in animals. They can be caused by various parasites, from viruses, fungi and bacteria, to other plants, insects and mites.
## Symptoms 
 The symptoms of gall disease on Alstonia Scholaris can vary depending on the pathogen involved. However, some common symptoms include:
* Abnormal growths or swellings on the leaves, stems, and/or roots of the plant
* Discoloration of the affected areas, which may turn yellow, brown, or black.
* Twisted or distorted growth of stems or leaves
* Reduced growth or stunted growth of the plant
* Premature leaves drop or defoliation.
* Die back of twigs or branches
* Formation of hard, woody galls on the plant, which may contain the pathogen responsible for the disease. 
## Cause 
 Various parasites, insects & mites
## Tips 
 * Select resistant cultivars when possible and purchase plants from a reputable nursery.
 * Do not buy plants that shows signs of swelling or galling.
 * When caring for susceptible plants, avoid injury or pruning wounds that may come in contact with the soil.
 * Use Tree Wrap to protect against string trimmer damage and keep your garden tools clean.
 * Provide winter protection with natural burlap so bark does not crack.
 * In many cases, existing galls can be removed with a sharp pruning knife. Destroy the infected plant tissue and treat the wound with pruning sealer. If the plant does not recover, remove and destroy it.
overview: Plant galls are abnormal outgrowths of plant tissues.

Content:
## Overview 
 * Fungus overwinters on dead foliage on the ground.
* Spores dispersed by wind.
* High moisture encourages fungal growth. 
## Symptoms 
 * Yellow or chlorotic spots on leaves.
* Dark olive green spots on leaves and fruit.
* Maybe a velvety growth on spots on the undersides of leaves.
* Twisting of leaves.
* Distorted leaves.
* Severely infected leaves turn yellow and drop from trees. 
## Cause 
 Fungus Venturia inaequalis 
## Tips 
 * Remove all fallen leaves from trees in the fall and compost to prevent any disease infestations in the debris.
* It may be necessary to add Zinc and fertilizer-grade urea in the fall to speed leaf drop, then add lime to fallen leaves.
* Using fungicide may be necessary for areas where leaves remain wet for periods of more than 9 hours.
* Fungicides such as copper soaps and Bordeaux mixture should be applied if there is a chance of a wet period as soon as leaf tips emerge.
overview:
* Fungus overwinters on dead foliage on the ground.
* Spores dispersed by wind.
* High moisture encourages fungal growth.

Content:
## Overview 
 Spores can overwinter in twigs or fruit remaining on the tree and spread during rainfall. 
## Symptoms 
 * Purple flecks or circular lesions which are brown in the center and purple at the margin.
* Red flecks, purple lesions and/or brown-black rings on fruit. 
## Cause 
 Fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa
## Tips 
 * Remove dead wood, mummified fruit, and cankers from trees to reduce the spread of disease.
* Burn any pruning that has been made from the tree.
* Controlling the disease by applying fungicides on silver tips to harvest.
overview: Spores can overwinter in twigs or fruit remaining on the tree and spread during rainfall.

Content:
## Overview 
 * Fungus needs two hosts to complete its lifecycle.
* It forms a gall on Eastern red cedar.
* The spores of the fungus are carried by the wind from the red cedar to the apple.
* It is important to exercise caution when planting apple trees close to Eastern red cedar. 
## Symptoms 
 * Bright orange or yellow patches on the top side of leaves surrounded by a red band and small black spots in the center.
* By mid-summer, cup-like structures called aecia form on the leaf undersides; these become covered in tubular structures from which spores are released. 
## Cause 
 Fungus Gymnosporangium juniperi virginianae 
## Tips 
 * Plant disease-resistant varieties where possible.
* Remove nearby red cedar.
* If growing susceptible varieties in proximity to red cedar, follow a fungicide program.
overview: It forms a gall on Eastern red cedar.

Content:
## Overview 
 Leaf curl disease of Arjun plant is a viral disease that affects the leaves of the Arjun tree (Terminalia arjuna). The disease is transmitted by whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci) in a persistent manner.
## Symptoms 
 *	Curling and crinkling of leaves, which may also become thickened and have a leathery texture.
 *	The leaves may also show discoloration, with yellow or white patches appearing on the upper surface of the leaves.
 *	In severe cases, the leaves may become distorted and stunted, and the growth of the plant may be affected.
## Cause 
 Begomovirus
## Tips 
 *	The use of insecticides to control whiteflies, which are the vectors of the virus. However, it is important to use these chemicals judiciously and in a manner that minimizes harm to the environment.
 *	Cultural practices such as removing infected leaves and destroying them can also help to reduce the spread of the disease.
 *	Planting resistant varieties of Arjun tree is also recommended as a long-term solution for preventing the disease.
overview: Leaf curl disease of Arjun plant is a viral disease that affects the leaves of the Arjun tree (Terminalia arjuna).

Content:
## Overview 
 Leaf spot disease of bael plant is a fungal disease that affects the leaves of the bael tree (Aegle marmelos).
## Symptoms 
 * The appearance of small, circular or irregularly shaped spots on the leaves. These spots may be brown or black in color, with a yellow halo surrounding them.
 * As the disease progresses, the spots may merge and cause the leaves to turn yellow, wither, and eventually drop off.
## Cause 
 Fungi like Alternaria & Phyllosticta
## Tips 
 * The use of fungicides to control the spread of the fungus.
 * Maintaining good sanitation practices, such as cleaning garden tools and avoiding overcrowding of plants, can also help to prevent the disease from spreading.
 * Planting resistant cultivars of bael tree is also recommended as a long-term solution for preventing the disease.
overview: Leaf spot disease of bael plant is a fungal disease that affects the leaves of the bael tree (Aegle marmelos).

Content:
## Overview 
 Infection of fruit is more likely if there are rainfalls close to harvest. 
## Symptoms 
 * Light-colored circular lesions on leaves inside the tree canopy which develop a powdery appearance. 
* Lesions may coalesce to cover the leaf. 
* If the infection is severe, leaves may blister and infected shoots may be distorted and stunted.
* Infected fruits may have slightly depressed areas on the surface containing fungal hyphae (filamentous fungal structures). 
## Cause 
 Fungus Podosphaera clandestina 
## Tips 
 Management of powdery mildew in cherry is reliant on the application of appropriate fungicides and cultural practices which promote good air circulation around tree canopies to lower humidity.
overview: Infection of fruit is more likely if there are rainfalls close to harvest.

Content:
## Overview 
 Spores can overwinter in twigs or fruit remaining on the tree and spread during rainfall.
## Symptoms
  *  Black or dark brown spots on the leaves that may spread and join together, causing the leaves to wilt and die.
  *  The bark of the tree becomes cracked and dark, with sunken cankers that exude a sticky liquid.
  *  The branches of the tree may become distorted and die back.
  *  The tree may show signs of stunted growth, reduced vigor, and overall decline.
## Cause 
 Fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa
## Tips 
 * Remove dead wood, mummified fruit, and cankers from trees to reduce the spread of disease.
 * Burn any pruning that has been made from the tree.
 * Controlling the disease by applying fungicides on silver tips to harvest.
overview: Spores can overwinter in twigs or fruit remaining on the tree and spread during rainfall.

Content:
## Overview 
 Coffee Rust disease does not affect rice plants, but coffee plants. However, to answer your question, coffee rust disease starts when spores of the fungal pathogen Hemileia vastatrix come into contact with a coffee plant. The spores can be spread by wind or rain, or they can be present in infected plant debris or soil. Once the spores land on a coffee plant, they germinate and penetrate the leaf tissue, where they form yellow-orange powdery spots on the upper surface of the leaves.
## Symptoms 
 * Yellow-orange powdery spots on the upper surface of the leaves.
* Premature dropping of leaves.
* Defoliation, which can lead to reduced growth and yield.
* Thin, spindly branches due to reduced photosynthesis.
* Reduced quality of the coffee beans due to reduced growth and yield. 
## Cause 
 Fungal pathogen( Hemileia vastatrix ) 
## Tips 
 Coffee rust can be partially controlled by the timely application of fungicide sprays during wet seasons. Plantations in some areas have been moved to higher and cooler altitudes, 1,800 to 2,100 metres (6,000 to 7,000 feet), at which the rust fungus has difficulty reproducing, though global warming is expected to further the spread of the disease into these areas. There is evidence that shade-grown coffees, which are not grown as monocultures, are somewhat less susceptible, as the agroforestry practice of mixing tree crops greatly slows the spread of the disease. Additionally, resistant varieties of Robusta coffee (Coffea canefora) have been developed, but the beans are generally considered to be of lower quality than those of the vulnerable Arabica plants (C. arabica). One resistant variety, Lempira, was widely planted in Honduras but lost its resistance to the disease in 2017, resulting in crop losses in that country. No resistant varieties have been shown to be impervious to all races of the fungus.
overview: The disease starts when spores of the fungal pathogen Hemileia vastatrix come into contact with a coffee plant.

Content:
## Overview 
 The infestation of red spider mites starts when the tiny arthropods called Tetranychus urticae come into contact with a coffee plant. These mites feed on the underside of the coffee plant leaves, causing damage to the plant tissue. The feeding activity of the mites can lead to the development of stippling or small, white or yellow spots on the leaves. The mites can also cause webbing on the leaves and stems of the coffee plant. 
## Symptoms 
 * Fine webbing on the leaves and stems.
* Yellowing or bronzing of the leaves.
* Stippling or small, white or yellow spots on the leaves.
* Leaf drop and defoliation, which can lead to reduced growth and yield.
* Presence of tiny, red or brown mites on the leaves and stems.
## Cause 
 Insect( Red spider mite ) 
## Tips 
 * Use miticides: Apply appropriate miticides to the affected coffee plants to control the mite population, but follow recommended application rates and safety guidelines to avoid environmental harm. Apply the miticide at the right time to target the mites when they are most vulnerable.
* Use natural predators: Introduce natural predators of coffee red spider mites, such as ladybugs or predatory mites, to the coffee fields to help control the mite population.
* Improve soil and water management: Maintain good soil fertility and drainage, and avoid overwatering or underwatering the coffee plants. This can help to reduce the risk of mite infestation and promote healthy plant growth.
* Use intercropping techniques: Interplant coffee with legumes or other crops to create a diverse ecosystem that can help control mite populations and reduce the risk of infestation.
* Monitor the coffee fields regularly: Regularly inspect the coffee fields for signs of mite infestation, such as stippling or webbing on the leaves, and take appropriate measures to control the infestation as soon as it is detected.
* Practice good agricultural practices: Use good agricultural practices such as proper pruning, weeding, and sanitation to help prevent the buildup of mite populations and reduce the risk of infestation.
overview: The infestation of red spider mites starts when the tiny arthropods called Tetranychus urticae come into contact with a coffee plant.

Content:
## Overview
 It survives in plant residues in the soil for long periods of time.
During the spring, the spores are carried onto the lower leaves by rain splashes and wind.
Its lifecycle is favored by elevated temperatures (25 to 30Â°C), high humidity (dews, fogs), and leaf wetness for prolonged periods of time.
Hot, dry weather hinders its development.
Symptoms vary slightly between different plant varieties.
The fungus completes its lifecycle (from infection to the production of new spores) in 14-21 days in a susceptible variety and in 21-28 days in a resistant one.  
## Symptoms 
 Small necrotic (brown or tan) spots that may have a yellow chlorotic halo appear on lower leaves, usually before flowering. 
Gradually these lesions will turn grayish and appear on younger leaves, too. 
As the disease progresses, they enlarge into elongated, rectangular lesions that run parallel to the leaf veins. 
In optimal conditions (warm temperatures, high humidity and wet leaves), they can coalesce and engulf the whole leaf. 
If this happens before grain filling there can be considerable yield losses. 
The leaf blight can weaken the plants and sometimes soften the stalks, leading to lodging. 
## Cause 
 Fungus Cercospora zeae-maydis 
## Tips 
 * Always consider an integrated approach with preventive measures and biological treatments if available.
* Foliar fungicide treatment is a way to manage the disease if it occurs at its early stages, but it has to be weighed against the weather conditions, the potential yield loss, and the susceptibility of the plant.
* Fungicides containing pyraclostrobin and strobilurin, or combinations of azoxystrobin and propiconazole, prothioconazole, and trifloxystrobin work well to control the fungus.
overview: It survives in plant residues in the soil for long periods of time.

Content:
## Overview 
 The disease is spread by wind-borne spores.
Some of the most popularly grown sweet corn varieties have little or no resistance to the disease. 
## Symptoms 
 Oval or elongated cinnamon brown pustules on upper and lower surfaces of leaves;
pustules rupture and release powdery red spores;
pustules turn dark brown-black as they mature and release dark brown powdery spores;
if infection is severe, pustules may appear on tassels and ears and leaves may begin to yellow;
in partially resistant corn hybrids, symptoms appear as chlorotic or necrotic flecks on the leaves which release little or no spore. 
## Cause 
 Fungus Puccinia sorghi 
## Tips 
 * The most effective method of controlling the disease is to plant resistant hybrids.
* The application of appropriate fungicides may provide some degree of control and reduce disease severity.
* Fungicides are more effective when the amount of secondary inoculum is still low, generally when plants only have a few rust pustules per leaf.
overview:
The disease is spread by wind-borne spores.
Some of the most popularly grown sweet corn varieties have little or no resistance to the disease.

Content:
## Overview 
 The disease mainly spreads through rain splash and wind. 
## Symptoms 
 In the beginning we will notice elliptical gray-green lesions on leaves.
As the disease process this lesions become pale gray to tan color.
Later stage the lesions looks dirty due to dark gray spores particularly under lower leaf surface.
The disease can be easily identified in the field due to its long, narrow lesions which are unrestricted by veins. 
## Cause 
 Fungus Exserohilum turcicum 
## Tips 
 * Follow proper tillage to reduce fungus inoculum from crop debris.
* Follow crop rotation with non-host crops.
* Grow available resistant varieties.
* In severe cases of disease incidence, apply a suitable fungicide.
overview: The disease mainly spreads through rain splash and wind.

Content:
## Overview 
 Cotton aphid leaf disease starts when cotton aphids (Aphis gossypii and Aphis craccivora) infest cotton plants and begin to feed on the sap of the leaves. As the aphids feed, they secrete a sticky substance called honeydew, which can attract other pests and fungal diseases, including sooty mold. The honeydew can also cover the leaves, reducing their photosynthetic capacity and leading to reduced plant growth and yield. 
## Symptoms 
 * Stunted growth: Infested cotton plants may exhibit stunted growth and reduced vigor.
* Yellowing leaves: The leaves of infested cotton plants may turn yellow and become distorted.
* Leaf curling: The leaves of infested cotton plants may curl and become deformed.
* Honeydew: Cotton aphids excrete a sticky substance called honeydew, which can accumulate on the leaves and stems of the plant.
* Sooty mold: The honeydew excreted by cotton aphids can also lead to the growth of a black, sooty mold on the leaves and stems of the plant.
* Reduced yield: In severe cases, cotton aphids can significantly reduce the yield and quality of cotton crops. 
## Cause 
 Aphid Species (including Aphis gossypii, Aphis craccivora) 
## Tips 
 * Consult industry Insecticide Resistance Management Strategies because it is important not to rely on insecticides alone.
* Aphid levels should be monitored at least weekly from seedling emergence through to defoliation.
* Controlling brassica weeds and other hosts such as marshmallows, capeweed and thistles between seasons will help reduce aphid pressure. 
* Cotton aphid populations build rapidly as spring temperatures increase. At this time, beneficial insects can play a very important role in suppressing aphid populations, so it is important to consider their populations too when assessing aphid spray thresholds.
* In addition to beneficial numbers, consider the current growing conditions. If crops have good growing conditions at the time of infestation (i.e., good soil moisture), they are more likely to be able to compensate for aphid damage compared to moisture stressed plants.
overview: Cotton aphid leaf disease starts when cotton aphids begin to feed on the sap of the leaves.

Content:
## Overview 
 Cotton bacterial blight leaf disease starts when the bacterium, Xanthomonas campestris pv. malvacearum, infects cotton plants through natural openings or wounds on the leaves. The bacteria can survive in plant debris and soil for several years and can be transmitted through contaminated seed, equipment, or water. The disease can also be spread by wind, rain, or insect vectors.
Once the bacteria infect a cotton plant, they can cause water-soaked lesions that later turn brown or black. The lesions can spread rapidly, leading to defoliation of the plant and reduced yield. Warm and humid weather conditions can promote the spread of the disease. 
## Symptoms 
 * Water-soaked lesions: The symptoms of the disease start as small, water-soaked lesions on the leaves, stems, and bolls of the cotton plant.
* Lesion expansion: As the disease progresses, the lesions expand and become angular in shape, with a yellow halo around them.
* Leaf drop: Infected leaves may drop prematurely, leading to the defoliation of the plant.
* Reduced yield: In severe cases, bacterial blight can lead to significant yield losses and reduced fiber quality.
* Shoot dieback: The disease can also cause shoot dieback and blackening of the stem.
* Wilting: Infected plants may wilt and die prematurely. 
## Cause 
 Xanthomonas Bacteria 
## Tips 
 * Diseased plant debris should be removed and burnt.
* Deep ploughing after harvest helps reduce disease incidence.
* Crop rotation, late sowing, early thinning, good tillage, early irrigation, and adding potash to soil help reduce disease incidence.
* Since the bacteria inhabit seeds internally or externally, seed treatment is an effective means to control the disease. 
* Bacteria occurring externally on seeds can be destroyed by immersing seeds in sulphuric acid for 10-15 minutes, then rinsing thoroughly by suspending them in water to remove acid, drying, and finally treating with Agrosan GN, Ceresan, etc. To remove bacteria lying inside the seeds, the use of antibiotics is recommended. Seeds may be soaked overnight in 1000 ppm of streptomycin for the purpose.
The use of resistant varieties is the best and most effective control measure. Some of them are – HC 9, BJA 592, Reba-B 50, Badnawar-I, K-4005, DHY 286, Khandawa-2, 70 IH- 480/3, and so on.
overview: The disease can be spread by wind, rain, or insect vectors.

Content:
## Overview 
 Plants infected with powdery mildew look as if they have been dusted with flour.
Powdery mildew usually starts off as circular, powdery white spots, which can appear on leaves, stems, and sometimes fruit.
Powdery mildew usually covers the upper part of the leaves but may grow on the undersides as well.
Young foliage is most susceptible to damage. Leaves turn yellow and dry out.
The fungus might cause some leaves to twist, break, or become disfigured.
The white spots of powdery mildew will spread to cover most of the leaves or affected areas.
The leaves, buds, and growing tips will become disfigured as well. These symptoms usually appear late in the growing season.  
## Symptoms 
 * White powdery spots: The disease typically starts as small, white powdery spots on the leaves, stems, and bolls of the cotton plant.
* Leaf distortion: As the disease progresses, the affected leaves may become distorted, curled, or twisted.
* Stunted growth: Infected cotton plants may exhibit stunted growth and reduced vigor.
* Reduced yield: In severe cases, powdery mildew can significantly reduce the yield and quality of cotton crops.
* Premature defoliation: Infected leaves may drop prematurely, leading to defoliation of the plant.
* The stem blackening: In some cases, the stem of the infected plant may become blackened. 
## Cause 
 Fungus ( the Oidium gossypii ) 
## Tips 
 * Once plants are heavily infected, it’s very difficult to get rid of the disease, so focus on preventing it from spreading to other plants. 
* Remove all infected foliage, stems, and fruit and destroy them, either by throwing them in the trash or by burning. 
* Do not compost any infected plant, as the disease can still be spread by the wind and persist in the composted materials.
* After pruning off infected parts, do not allow pruning shears to touch healthy leaves. First sterilize your pruners with rubbing alcohol.
overview: Plants infected with powdery mildew look as if they have been dusted with flour.

Content:
## Overview 
 The disease affects mainly older leaves of mature plants. Reddish lesions will appear on these leaves during the early stages of the infection. As the disease progresses, the lesions enlarge and turn white to light brown or gray in the center with a purple, dark brown or blackish margin. The lesions are circular or irregular in shape and vary in size depending on the time of infection. A concentric zonation of the spots occurs, alternating dark and light brown or red margins. Affected leaves eventually become pale in color and finally fall off.  
## Symptoms 
 * Circular spots: The disease typically starts as small, circular spots on the leaves of the cotton plant.
* Brown lesions: As the disease progresses, the spots may turn brown and develop a target-like appearance, with concentric rings of light and dark brown.
* Leaf drop: Infected leaves may drop prematurely, leading to defoliation of the plant.
* Reduced yield: In severe cases, target spot disease can significantly reduce the yield and quality of cotton crops.
* Stem cankers: The disease can also cause cankers or lesions on the stem of the cotton plant.
* Boll rot: In some cases, target spot disease can lead to boll rot and reduced fiber quality. 
## Cause 
 Fungus ( Corynespora cassiicola ) 
## Tips 
 Rotate to a non-host such as corn if possible.
Plant multiple, high-yielding, stable-performing varieties adapted to the field environment. Although differences in variety susceptibility have been noted, the highest yielding varieties in a given trial have also occasionally been characterized by the highest disease ratings and greatest percent defoliation.
Properly apply nitrogen and plant growth regulators to produce sufficient vegetative growth to support fruiting bodies without allowing the plant to become rank.
When considering fungicide applications, keep in mind that while two applications of fungicide have consistently reduced disease and defoliation due to target spot, yield responses have been variable in Tennessee.
overview: The disease affects mainly older leaves of mature plants.

Content:
## Overview 
 The plant begins to die backwards form the top of a branch.
## Symptoms 
 *	Die back phase: The plant begins to die backward from the top of a branch.
 *	Young shoots, leaves, and fruits are readily attached, while they are still tender. The greenish color of the growing tip is changed to dark brown and later to black necrotic areas extending backward.
 *	The fungus develops from the infected twigs and then petiole and young leaves which may drop down or fall leaving the dried twigs without leaves.
 *	Fruit and leaf infection phase: Fruit and leaf infection is generally seen during rainy season crops. Pin-head spots are first seen on unripe fruits, which gradually enlarge.
 *	Spots are dark brown in color, sunken, circular, and have minute black stromata in the center of the lesion, which produce creamy spore masses in moist weather.
 *	Several spots coalesce to form bigger lesions.
 *	The infected area on unripe fruits becomes corky and hardy and often develops cracks in case of severe infection.
 *	Unopened buds and flowers are also affected which causes their shedding.
 *	On leaves, the fungus causes necrotic lesions usually ashy grey, and bear fruiting bodies at the tip or on the margin.

## Cause 
 Fungus Botryosphaeriaceae 
## Tips 
 *	Mark diseased wood and remove branches or entire vines. 
 *	Prune later in the dormant period to avoid the peak of spore production.
 *	Extra irrigation may help manage symptom severity but avoid overhead irrigation.
overview: The plant begins to die backwards form the top of a branch.
The disease favors rainy weather; spores may ooze out during rain.

Content:
## Overview 
 The leaf and berry symptoms may occur together in a single cane or may show symptoms on only one part.
The severe infestation of measles kills the grapevine in a single year which is commonly called apoplexy.
The symptoms are common in 5 to 7-year-old vineyards.
The prune wounds helps in pathogen entrance and establishment. 
## Symptoms 
 Symptom appears on leaves, trunk, canes and berries. 
On leaves we will see intervenaial striping looks like tiger strips. 
White cultivars shows chlorotic and necrotic strips where as red cultivars shows red areas and necrotic strips. 
On berries we will see superficial spots and later may coalesce making berries appear black. 
Trunk/arm/cordons shows dark brown black vascular streaking and oozes dark sap when we cut trunk. 
Some time this measles in associate with numerous secondary wood rotting fungi which decorate the vineyard completely. 
## Cause 
 Fungus 
## Tips 
 Till date there is no effective method to control this disease.
Remove the infected berries, leaves and trunk and destroy them.
Protect the prune wounds to minimize fungal infection using wound sealant (5% boric acid in acrylic paint) or essential oil or suitable fungicides.
overview: The severe infestation of measles kills the grapevine in a single year.

Content:
## Overview 
 Common in tropical and subtropical grapes.
The disease appear late in the season.
Cynthiana and Cabernet Sauvignon are susceptible to this pathogen. 
## Symptoms 
 On leaf surface we will see lesions which are irregularly shaped (2 to 25 mm in diameter). 
Initially lesions are dull red to brown in color turn black later. 
If disease is severe this lesions may coalesce. 
On berries we can see symptom similar to black rot but the entire clusters will collapse. 
## Cause 
 Fungus 
## Tips 
 Fungicides sprayed for other diseases in the season may help to reduce this disease.
overview:
Common in tropical and subtropical grapes.
The disease appear late in the season.
Cynthiana and Cabernet Sauvignon are susceptible to this pathogen.

Content:
## Overview 
 The spores can be spread by wind or rain, or they can be present in infected plant debris or soil. Once the spores land on jamun, they germinate and penetrate the leaf tissue, where they form yellow-orange powdery spots on the upper surface of the leaves.
## Symptoms 
 * Yellow-orange powdery spots on the upper surface of the leaves.
 * Premature dropping of leaves.
 * Defoliation, which can lead to reduced growth and yield.
 * Thin, spindly branches due to reduced photosynthesis.
## Cause 
 Fungal pathogen( Hemileia vastatrix )
## Tips 
 *	Fungicides can be used to control rust disease in plants. It is important to choose the right fungicide for the specific type of rust disease and to follow the instructions carefully.
 *	Cultural practices such as crop rotation, proper spacing, and good sanitation practices can help to reduce the incidence of rust disease in plants.
 *	Proper management of environmental factors such as temperature, humidity, and irrigation can help to prevent the development and spread of rust disease in plants.
overview: The spores can be spread by wind or rain
code: or they can be present in infected plant debris or soil.

## Overview 
 Unopened buds and flowers are affected which causes their shedding.
## Symptoms 
 *	Die back phase: The plant begins to die backward from the top of a branch.
 *	Young shoots, leaves, and fruits are readily attached, while they are still tender. The greenish color of the growing tip is changed to dark brown and later to black necrotic areas extending backward.
 *	The fungus develops from the infected twigs and then petiole and young leaves which may drop down or fall leaving the dried twigs without leaves.

 *	Several spots coalesce to form bigger lesions.
 *	The infected area on unripe fruits becomes corky and hardy and often develops cracks in case of severe infection.
 *	Unopened buds and flowers are also affected which causes their shedding.
 *	On leaves, the fungus causes necrotic lesions usually ashy grey, and bear fruiting bodies at the tip or on the margin.

## Cause
 Fungus Botryosphaeriaceae
## Tips
 *	Mark diseased wood and remove branches or entire vines.

Content:
## Overview 
 Leaf curl disease of Arjun plant is a viral disease that affects the leaves of lemon.
## Symptoms 
 *	Curling and crinkling of leaves, which may also become thickened and have a leathery texture.
 *	The leaves may also show discoloration, with yellow or white patches appearing on the upper surface of the leaves.
 *	In severe cases, the leaves may become distorted and stunted, and the growth of the plant may be affected.
## Cause 
 Begomovirus
## Tips 
 The use of insecticides to control whiteflies, which are the vectors of the virus. However, it is important to use these chemicals judiciously and in a manner that minimizes harm to the environment.
overview: Curling and crinkling of leaves.

Content:
## Overview 
 The fungus attacks the young leaves, inflorescence, twigs, and the fruits and the symptoms vary according to the plant parts infected. When the young leaves and inflorescence are infected, small blister-like spots develop on them. On twigs and floral axis the symptoms appear as black necrotic patches; the disease spreads rapidly during the rainy season and covers the twigs and floral axis causing them to turn black and become dry.
When the fruits are attacked, black spots are formed on them and their skin becomes discoloured. The fruit pulp beneath the spot becomes hard. The infected fruit-skin later cracks and the adjacent area decays at ripening. Infected fruits and leaves may fall off the tree prematurely.
  
## Symptoms 
 The disease causes serious losses to young shoots, flowers and fruits It is also affects fruits during storage.
The disease produces leaf spot, blossom blight, wither tip, twig blight and fruit rot symptoms. Tender shoots and foliage are easily affected which ultimately cause „die back‟ of young branches. Older twigs may also be infected through wounds which in severe cases may be fatal.
Depending on the prevailing weather conditions blossom blight may vary in severity from slight to a heavy infection of the panicles. Black spots develop on panicles as well as on fruits. Severe infection destroys the entire inflorescence resulting in no setting of fruits. Young infected fruits develop black spots, shrivel and drop off.
Fruits infected at mature stage carry the fungus into storage and cause considerable loss during storage, transit and marketing. 
## Cause 
 Fungus ( Colletotrichum gloeosporioides ) 
## Tips 
 Seed treatment with BIODISTINCTION XTRA helps to control seed coat infections.
Fungicides should be mixed with INTEGRA 3ml/20l, which improves the efficacy of the fungicide by acting as a sticker, spreader, wetter and penetrant.
Alternating different fungicides throughout a plant’s season prevents the fungus from developing resistance over any of the fungicides.
Proper fertilization and watering during summer must be done to maintain tree vigour, which is important for keeping the infection of twigs away.
Tree sanitation is essential. Diseased twigs should be pruned and burnt along with fallen leaves.
Pruning should be followed by spraying of suitable fungicides such as Bordeaux mixture (6:6: 50), 0.15% Cuprocide, Fytolan or Blitox-50, etc., which proves effective. Four to five sprayings between January to July give satisfactory control to the disease. A combination of Captan with Zineb for spraying the trees has been reported very effective. Prakash and Mishra have reported in 2001 that spraying of Bavistin (0.1%) at fortnight interval is quite effective against mango anthracnose.
Post-harvest fruit treatment in hot water at 51°C for 15 minutes is required to control fruit-rot.
overview:
The fungus attacks the young leaves, inflorescence, twigs, and the fruits and the symptoms vary according to the plant parts infected. When the young leaves and inflorescence are infected, small blister-like spots develop on them. On twigs and floral axis the symptoms appear as black necrotic patches; the disease spreads rapidly during the rainy season and covers the twigs and floral axis causing them to turn black and become dry.
When the fruits are attacked, black spots are formed on them and their skin becomes discoloured. The fruit pulp beneath the spot becomes hard. The infected fruit-skin later cracks and the adjacent area decays at ripening. Infected fruits and leaves may fall off the tree prematurely.

Content:
## Overview 
 The disease is caused by a strain of the bacteria Xanthomonas citri. It can survive up to 8 months in living tissues. It infects trees through wounds and natural openings. The pathogens can spread from tree to tree or between fields by wind-driven rain or through implements used for management activities such as pruning. Alternatively, the spreading occurs via infected plant material or through contact in the case of fruits. The most favorable temperature for an infection with bacterial black spot is between 25 and 30 °C. High humidity also fosters infections. Windbreaks or the planting of tree species with dense foliage around the orchard can reduce the spreading of the disease. 
## Symptoms 
 The disease is noticed on leaves, leaf stalks, stems, twigs, branches and fruits, initially producing water soaked lesions, later turning into typical canker.
On leaves, water soaked irregular satellite to angular raised lesions measuring 1-4 mm in diameter are formed. These lesions are light yellow in colour, initially with yellow halo but with age enlarge or coalesce to form irregular necrotic cankerous patches with dark brown colour.
On fruits, water-soaked, dark brown to black coloured lesions are observed which gradually developed into cankerous, raised or flat spots. These spots grow bigger usually up to 1 to 5 mm in diameter, which covers / almost the whole fruit.
These spots often, burst extruding gummy substances containing highly contagious bacterial cells. 
## Cause 
 Bacterium ( Xanthomonas campestris ) 
## Tips 
 Prune flowering trees during blooming when wounds heal fastest.
Remove wilted or dead limbs well below infected areas.
Avoid pruning in early spring and fall when bacteria are most active.
Treat all pruning cuts immediately with Tanglefoot® Tree Pruning Sealer and make sure to disinfect your pruning equipment — one part bleach to 4 parts water — after each cut.
If using string trimmers around the base of trees avoid damaging bark with breathable Tree Wrap to prevent infection.
Brush bark with white latex paint diluted with water to reduce bark-damaging temperature fluctuations.
Research has shown that copper fungicides have some success against this stone fruit problem. However, results are inconsistent. We recommend using it as one part of a total management program.
Remove weeds and grass from around the base of young trees to improve air circulation and keep the trunk and crown dry.
Organocide® Plant Doctor is an earth-friendly systemic fungicide that works its way through the entire plant to combat a large number of diseases on ornamentals, turf, fruit and more. Mix 1/3 to 3/4 oz per gallon of water and paint or spray over pruning wounds and surrounding areas.
overview: The disease is caused by a strain of the bacteria Xanthomonas citri. It can survive up to 8 months in living tissues. It infects trees through wounds and natural openings. The pathogens can spread from tree to tree or between fields by wind-driven rain or through implements used for management activities such as pruning. Alternatively, the spreading occurs via infected plant material or through contact in the case of fruits. The most favorable temperature for an infection with bacterial black spot is between 25 and 30 °C. High humidity also fosters infections. Windbreaks or the planting of tree species with dense foliage around the orchard can reduce the spreading of the disease.

Content:
## Overview 
 Adult mango nut weevil is an oval-shaped beetle with an elongated head that forms a snout. Female lay creamy-white, elliptical eggs singly on half mature (green) to ripe mango fruit. The puncture point is characterized by an incision on the fruit peel along with a light brown secretion. After 5-7 days, 1 mm long larvae hatch and tunnel through the flesh to reach the mango seeds. Usually, one larva is found feeding on each stone, sometimes up to 5. In some rare cases, the larvae will feed and pupate in the pulp. Adults usually emerge after fruits fall and undergo a period of suspended growth until new fruits appear on trees. When mangoes reach pea-size, they become active again and start feeding on leaves and mating. Long-range spreading of the bugs occurs through the transport of fruit, seeds, seedlings and/or cuttings containing larvae, pupae or adults. 
## Symptoms 
 Tunneling: Mango cutting weevil larvae tunnel into the trunk, branches, and fruit of the mango tree, causing extensive damage.
Wilting: Infested branches may wilt and die, leading to a reduction in tree vigor.
Fruit drop: Infested fruits may drop prematurely, leading to reduced yield.
Entry holes: Adult weevils may leave entry holes on the trunk and branches of the mango tree.
Sawdust: Infested areas may have sawdust-like material, which is the result of weevil feeding and tunneling.
  
## Cause 
 Insect ( Sternochetus mangiferae beetle ) 
## Tips 
 Destroying the affected fruits and exposing the hibernating weevils by digging the soil
Spraying the trees with Fenthion (0.01%)
overview: Adult mango nut weevil is an oval-shaped beetle with an elongated head that forms a snout. Female lay creamy-white, elliptical eggs singly on half mature (green) to ripe mango fruit. The puncture point is characterized by an incision on the fruit peel along with a light brown secretion. After 5-7 days, 1 mm long larvae hatch and tunnel through the flesh to reach the mango seeds. Usually, one larva is found feeding on each stone, sometimes up to 5. In some rare cases, the larvae will feed and pupate in the pulp. Adults usually emerge after fruits fall and undergo a period of suspended growth until new fruits appear on trees. When mangoes reach pea-size, they become active again and start feeding on leaves and mating. Long-range spreading of the bugs occurs through the transport of fruit, seeds, seedlings and/or cuttings containing larvae, pupae or adults.

Content:
## Overview 
 Botryosphaeria rhodina survives in plant necrotic tissue for long periods of time. It invades the vascular system of mango trees through wounds in the trunk and branches. The precise mechanism for the infection is not fully understood. Possible entry sites are wounds inflicted by insects (beetles) or mechanical injuries that occured during field work. The primary source of infection might be spores in the dead bark of twigs. They remain on the trees during the growing season and spread during the harvest period. Deficiency in iron, zinc and manganese may favor the outbreak of the disease. Water and freezing stress have also been related to this disease. The disease can occur at any time of the year but it is most conspicuous during late growth stages. 
## Symptoms 
 Infection of mango trees with the fungus Botryosphaeria rhodina manifests itself in dry twigs and can lead to complete defoliation. During the first stage of the disease, the barks become discolored and turn darker. In the following stages, young twigs start withering at the base, extending outwards until the leaves become affected. As the veins turn brown, leaves curl upwards and eventually fall off the tree. In the final stages of dieback, twigs and branches secrete gum. Initially, small gum droplets become visible, but as the disease progresses the entire branch or trunk may be covered. In severe cases, the tree bark or whole branches die and crack. 
  
## Cause 
 Fungus ( Lasiodiplodia theobromae , Colletotrichum gloeosporioides , Fusarium moniliforme ) 
## Tips 
 Measures such as the sterilization of budding knives, placement of budded trees in a dry environment, and gradual exposure to full sunlight have been suggested to control the dieback of grafted seedlings.
The disease can be controlled by pruning diseased twigs 2-3 inches below the affected portion and spraying Copper Oxychloride (0.3%) on infected trees. Copper Oxychloride (0.3%) is pasted on the cut ends of pruned twigs.
overview: Botryosphaeria rhodina survives in plant necrotic tissue for long periods of time. It invades the vascular system of mango trees through wounds in the trunk and branches. The precise mechanism for the infection is not fully understood. Possible entry sites are wounds inflicted by insects (beetles) or mechanical injuries that occured during field work. The primary source of infection might be spores in the dead bark of twigs. They remain on the trees during the growing season and spread during the harvest period. Deficiency in iron, zinc and manganese may favor the outbreak of the disease. Water and freezing stress have also been related to this disease. The disease can occur at any time of the year but it is most conspicuous during late growth stages.

Content:
## Overview 
 The symptoms are caused by different species of midges, Procontarinia sp. Adult midges are 1-2 mm in size and die within 24 hours of emergence after copulation and egg deposition. Eggs are laid on almost all tree parts, but they are predominantly found on leaves. When they hatch, the larvae penetrate the tissues and inflict damage depending on the organ they affect. Floral parts that are fed upon can consequently dry up and fall to the ground due to extensive feeding. Mature larvae migrate or fall onto the upper soil layers, where they enter the pupal stage. The emergence of adults usually takes place in the afternoon and is favored by cool temperatures (20°C) and 60-82% relative humidity. There can be up to 3-4 pest generations over the period of January to March in the northern hemisphere.  
## Symptoms 
 The symptoms appear predominantly on the leaves, but occasionally also on the buds, inflorescences and young fruits of mango trees. The parts infested by this midge become covered with many small, raised galls or blisters. Each wart-like blister or gall is 3-4 mm in size and contains a yellow larva that feeds on tree tissue. In the early stages, the site of egg deposition appears as a small red spot. Heavily-affected leaves may deform, show reduced photosynthesis, and drop prematurely.  Infested inflorescences may be unable to open. The small exit holes on the underside of leaves are remnants due to larval presence. These exit lesions may result in secondary fungal infections. Young fruits also display exit holes at the base of the stem. Severely infected mango shoots have almost no inflorescence, which can considerably reduce the yield.  
## Cause 
 Insect ( Procontarinia matteiana fly ) 
## Tips 
 Planting resistant mango varieties
Maintenance of field hygiene/ sanitation
Proper weed control (weeds are alternate hosts of the pests)
Pruning the infested branches
Mixed and intercropping farming reduces the pest population
Ploughing of the orchards exposes pupating and diapausing larvae to sun heat which kills them
Avoid movement of infested plants to new areas
Hand-picking the midges, especially if the population is not dense
Use of sticky traps to catch the flies
It is highly advisable to always mix the insecticide with INTEGRA 3ml/20l whenever spraying. This is a sticker, wetter, spreader and penetrant which greatly improves the efficacy of the chemical
Alternating the insecticides during the crop’s season helps in preventing resistance build up by the pest, which would be if a single chemical was used.
Timely control of the pest is very critical.
overview: The symptoms are caused by different species of midges, Procontarinia sp. Adult midges are 1-2 mm in size and die within 24 hours of emergence after copulation and egg deposition. Eggs are laid on almost all tree parts, but they are predominantly found on leaves. When they hatch, the larvae penetrate the tissues and inflict damage depending on the organ they affect. Floral parts that are fed upon can consequently dry up and fall to the ground due to extensive feeding. Mature larvae migrate or fall onto the upper soil layers, where they enter the pupal stage. The emergence of adults usually takes place in the afternoon and is favored by cool temperatures (20°C) and 60-82% relative humidity. There can be up to 3-4 pest generations over the period of January to March in the northern hemisphere.

Content:
## Overview 
 Oidium mangiferae survives from one season to the next as mycelium in dormant buds and as haustoria on old infected leaves.
After landing on the plant tissue, a conidium of O. mangiferae germinates, enters a stoma/pore and then grows. After two or three weeks, the fruiting bodies grow out of the stomata and release conidia into the air, to be carried to other plants or plant parts.
It usually takes about 7-10days from the time of infection to development of symptoms.
The disease is spread by wind-borne conidia from other mango trees or from within an infected tree’s canopy.
Initial infection with O. mangiferae is promoted by warm temperatures and moderate relative humidity, although development of the disease is favoured by cool, dry conditions.
The fungus survives under dense foliage during off-season. 
## Symptoms 
 The characteristic symptom of the disease is the white superficial powdery fungal growth on leaves, stalks of panicles, flowers and young fruits.
The affected flowers and fruits drop pre-maturely reducing the crop load considerably or might even prevent the fruit set.
The fungus parasitizes young tissues of all parts of the inflorescence, leaves and fruits.
Young leaves are attacked on both the sides but it is more conspicuous on the grower surface. Often these patches coalesce and occupy larger areas turning into purplish brown in colour
  
## Cause 
 Fungus ( Oidium mangiferae ) 
## Tips 
 Chemical Control Methods:
Alternate spraying of Wettable sulfur 0.2 percent (2 g Sulfex/liter), Tridemorph O.1 percent (1 ml Calixin/liter), and Bavistin at 0.1 % at 15 days intervals are recommended for effective control of this disease. The first spray should be given at the panicle emergence stage.
overview:
Oidium mangiferae survives from one season to the next as mycelium in dormant buds and as haustoria on old infected leaves.
After landing on the plant tissue, a conidium of O. mangiferae germinates, enters a stoma/pore and then grows. After two or three weeks, the fruiting bodies grow out of the stomata and release conidia into the air, to be carried to other plants or plant parts.
It usually takes about 7-10days from the time of infection to development of symptoms.
The disease is spread by wind-borne conidia from other mango trees or from within an infected tree’s canopy.
Initial infection with O. mangiferae is promoted by warm temperatures and moderate relative humidity, although development of the disease is favoured by cool, dry conditions.
The fungus survives under dense foliage during off-season.

Content:
## Overview 
 The fungi produce mycelium which is superficial and dark. They row on sugary secretions of the plant hoppers. Black encrustation is formed which affect the photosynthetic activity.
The fungus grows on the leaf surface on the sugary substances secreted by jassids, aphids and scale insects.
  
## Symptoms 
 The disease is common in the orchards where mealy bug, scale insect and hopper are not controlled efficiently.
The disease in the field is recognized by the presence of a black velvety coating, i.e., sooty mould on the leaf surface. In severe cases the trees turn completely black due to the presence of mould over the entire surface of twigs and leaves.
The severity of infection depends on the honey dew secretion by the above said insects. Honey dew secretions from insects sticks to the leaf surface and provide necessary medium for fungal growth.
  
## Cause 
 Fungus ( black, sooty mold ) 
## Tips 
 Pruning of affected branches and their prompt destruction, followed by spraying of Wettasulf (0.2% )+ Metacid (0.1 %)+ gum acacia (0.3%), helps to control the disease.
The fungal growth can be checked by spraying with 0.2% wettable sulfur.
Pruning of affected branches and their prompt destruction prevents the spread of the disease.
Spraying of 2% starch is found effective.
overview:
The fungi produce mycelium which is superficial and dark. They row on sugary secretions of the plant hoppers. Black encrustation is formed which affect the photosynthetic activity.
The fungus grows on the leaf surface on the sugary substances secreted by jassids, aphids and scale insects.

Content:
## Overview 
 Huanglongbing has a complex pathosystem (an ecosystem based on parasitism).
There are multiple strains, diverse hosts, several insect vectors, and different environmental conditions that affect the expression and spread of the disease.
Three forms of the disease are known (Asian, African, and American), and these are associated with different species and strains of Liberibactors that are disseminated by different species of citrus psyllid insect vectors.
The pathogen currently found in the US is Candidatus Liberibacter asiaticus.
Most citrus species, cultivars, and hybrids are susceptible to the disease.
Vectors of the Liberibacters include citrus psyllids Diaphorina citri and Trioza erytreae.
Huanglongbing can also be spread by grafting.
Transmission can occur in the nursery and in the orchard.
Non-citrus hosts have been identified as alternate hosts for the Liberibacters and the citrus psyllids, but their role is still unclear in the epidemiology of the disease. 
## Symptoms 
 Leaf symptoms of citrus greening include yellowing of one limb or one area of canopy, yellowing of leaf veins; 
blotchy mottling and/or green islands (spots) surrounded by completely yellow leaf tissue; 
twig and limbs begin to die back; 
fruits may drop prematurely and are often mishappen and lopsided; 
fruit has a bitter, salty taste. 
## Cause 
 Bacteria 
## Tips 
 Although dusting sulfur at 10-15 days intervals is effective, the treatment may cause handling hazards and toxicity in hot weather.
overview:
Huanglongbing has a complex pathosystem (an ecosystem based on parasitism).
There are multiple strains, diverse hosts, several insect vectors, and different environmental conditions that affect the expression and spread of the disease.
Three forms of the disease are known (Asian, African, and American), and these are associated with different species and strains of Liberibactors that are disseminated by different species of citrus psyllid insect vectors.
The pathogen currently found in the US is Candidatus Liberibacter asiaticus.
Most citrus species, cultivars, and hybrids are susceptible to the disease.
Vectors of the Liberibacters include citrus psyllids Diaphorina citri and Trioza erytreae.
Huanglongbing can also be spread by grafting.
Transmission can occur in the nursery and in the orchard.
Non-citrus hosts have been identified as alternate hosts for the Liberibacters and the citrus psyllids, but their role is still unclear in the epidemiology of the disease.

Periods of frequent rainfall during late bloom and early petal drop increase the likelihood of fruit and leaf infection.
The infection is rare during hot, dry weather.

Content:
## Overview 
 Disease emergence favored by warm, wet conditions.
The pathogen can enter a field on seed and transplants and can be spread within a field by wind-driven rain, clipping plants, and aerosols. 
## Symptoms 
 Water-soaked lesions that dry out and turn brown forming on the underside of the leaves;
raised brown cankers on stems;
cracked brown lesions on fruit. 
## Cause 
 Bacteria 
## Tips 
 nan
overview:
Disease emergence favored by warm, wet conditions.
The pathogen can enter a field on seed and transplants and can be spread within a field by wind-driven rain, clipping plants, and aerosols.

Content:
## Overview 
 Infection of fruit is more likely if there are rainfalls close to harvest.
 ## Symptoms
  * Light-colored circular lesions on leaves inside the tree canopy which develop a powdery appearance.
 * Lesions may coalesce to cover the leaf.
 * If the infection is severe, leaves may blister and infected shoots may be distorted and stunted.
 * Infected fruits may have slightly depressed areas on the surface containing fungal hyphae (filamentous fungal structures).
 ## Cause
  Fungus Podosphaera clandestina
 ## Tips
  Management of powdery mildew in pomegranate is reliant on the application of appropriate fungicides and cultural practices which promote good air circulation around tree canopies to lower humidity.
overview: Infection of fruit is more likely if there are rainfalls close to harvest.

Content:
## Overview 
 Mosaic virus disease is a viral infection that affects a wide range of plants, including vegetables, fruits, and ornamental plants. The disease is caused by several different viruses, including tobacco mosaic virus, cucumber mosaic virus, and tomato mosaic virus, among others.
## Symptoms 
 *	Mottled or streaked leaves.
 *	Yellowing of the leaves.
 *	Stunted growth.
 *	Deformed or distorted leaves or fruits.
 *	Reduced yield or quality of the fruit.
 
## Cause 
 Virus
## Tips 
 There is no cure for Mosaic Virus, diseased plants should be dug up, roots and all, then burnt. Prevention is the only measure you can take with this disease.
overview: Mosaic virus disease is a viral infection that affects a wide range of plants.

Content:
## Overview 
 Disease emergence favors cycles of wet and dry conditions with periods of high humidity and leaf wetness. 
## Symptoms 
 Dark lesions with yellow border which may form concentric rings of raised and sunken tissue on the leaves and stems;
lesions initially circular but become angular;
leaves become necrotic but remain attached to plant;
dark, dry lesions on tubers with leathery or corky texture and watery yellowy green margins. 
## Cause 
 Fungus 
## Tips 
 Removal of fallen leaves, inflorescences, and malformed fruits from the tree base
overview: Disease emergence favors cycles of wet and dry conditions with periods of high humidity and leaf wetness.

The pathogen can survive for several months to years in the soil.
The emergence of disease is favored by moist, cool conditions.
Infected tubers are a major cause of spreading the disease.

Content:
## Overview 
 Rice Brown Spot disease starts when spores of the fungal pathogen Bipolaris oryzae come into contact with a rice plant. The spores can be spread by wind or rain, or they can be present in infected plant debris or soil. Once the spores land on a rice plant, they germinate and penetrate the leaf tissue, where they form small, oval to circular, brownish or grayish spots that can enlarge over time. 
## Symptoms 
 * Small, oval to circular, brownish or grayish spots that appear on the leaves.
* The spots may have a yellow halo around them.
* The spots can coalesce to form larger lesions, which can cause defoliation.
* The infected leaves may turn yellow and drop off prematurely.
* The disease can also affect rice panicles, causing them to shrivel and turn brown. 
## Cause 
 Fungal pathogen( Bipolaris oryzae ) 
## Tips 
 Proper weed control
overview: Rice Brown Spot disease starts when spores of the fungal pathogen Bipolaris oryzae come into contact with a rice plant. The spores can be spread by wind or rain, or they can be present in infected plant debris or soil. Once the spores land on a rice plant, they germinate and penetrate the leaf tissue, where they form small, oval to circular, brownish or grayish spots that can enlarge over time.

Content:
## Overview 
 Rice Hispa disease starts when rice hispa beetles (Dicladispa armigera) feed on the leaves and stems of rice plants, causing damage to the plant tissue. The beetles are most active during the early stages of rice growth and development, and their activity is often associated with the onset of the monsoon season. 
## Symptoms 
 * Small, elongated, and irregular holes on the leaves.
* White, yellow, or brownish streaks on the leaves.
* Curled and distorted leaves.
* Stunted growth of the rice plant.
* Presence of small, black beetles on the leaves and stems.
* The beetles can also cause damage to the rice panicles, resulting in reduced yield. 
## Cause 
 Insect( Rice hispa beetle ) 
## Tips 
 Minimizing field movements from infected areas to non-infected zones
overview: Rice Hispa disease starts when rice hispa beetles (Dicladispa armigera) feed on the leaves and stems of rice plants, causing damage to the plant tissue. The beetles are most active during the early stages of rice growth and development, and their activity is often associated with the onset of the monsoon season.

Content:
## Overview 
 Rice leaf blast disease starts when spores of the fungal pathogen Magnaporthe oryzae come into contact with a rice plant. The spores can be spread by wind or rain, or they can be present in infected plant debris or soil. Once the spores land on a rice plant, they germinate and penetrate the leaf tissue, where they form small, circular lesions that can expand over time. 
## Symptoms 
 Leaf lesions: Small brown or grayish spots that appear on leaves, which can enlarge and merge to form larger lesions.
Collar rot: The fungus can infect the collar region of the rice stem, causing the stem to rot and break.
Neck blast: The fungus can infect the neck region of the rice stem, causing the stem to break, and the panicles to drop off.
Leaf blast: The fungus can infect the leaf tips, causing them to turn brown and die.
Sheath rot: The fungus can infect the sheath of the rice plant, causing it to rot, which can lead to reduced growth and yield.
Spikelet blast: The fungus can infect the developing rice grain, causing it to turn brown and shrivel up. 
## Cause 
 Fungal pathogen ( Magnaporthe oryzae ) 
## Tips 
 Ensuring proper spacing of the trees
overview: Rice leaf blast disease starts when spores of the fungal pathogen Magnaporthe oryzae come into contact with a rice plant. The spores can be spread by wind or rain, or they can be present in infected plant debris or soil. Once the spores land on a rice plant, they germinate and penetrate the leaf tissue, where they form small, circular lesions that can expand over time.

Content:
## Overview 
 Disease emergence is favored by dry weather and high relative humidity. 
## Symptoms 
 White powdery growth on the upper surfaces of leaves and stems;
infected areas stunted and distorted. 
## Cause 
 Fungus 
## Tips 
 Plant in sites with good air circulation and sun exposure;
do not overcrowd plants;
sanitize equipment regularly.
overview: Disease emergence is favored by dry weather and high relative humidity.
Disease emergence is favored by wet foliage for extended periods of time.

Bacteria survive on crop debris.
Disease emergence is favored by warm temperatures and wet weather.
Symptoms are very similar to other tomato diseases but only bacterial spots will cause a cut leaf to ooze bacterial exudate.
The disease is spread by infected seeds, wind-driven rain, diseased transplants, or infested soil.
Bacteria enter the plant through any natural openings on the leaves or any openings caused by injury to the leaves.

The disease can spread rapidly after plants have set fruit.
The movement of air-borne spores and contact with infested soil are causes for the spread of the disease.

Content:
## Overview 
 * The disease is favored by high relative humidity.
* Also a common disease in greenhouse tomato crops. 
## Symptoms 
 The older leaves exhibit pale greenish to yellow spots (without distinguishable margins) on upper surface.
Whereas the lower portion of this spots exhibit green to brown velvety fungal growth.
As the disease progress the spots may coalesce and appear brown.
The infected leaves become wither and die but stay attached to the plant.
The fungus also infects flowers and fruits.
The affected flowers become black and drop off.
The affected fruit intially shows smooth black irregular area on the stem end but later it becomes sunken, leathery and dry. 
## Cause 
 Fungus 
## Tips 
 Grow available resistant varieties.
Avoid leaf wetting and overhead application of water.
Follow proper spacing to provide good air circulation around the plants.
Remove the infected plant debris and burn them.
If the disease is severe scary suitable fungicide.
overview:
* The disease is favored by high relative humidity.
* Also a common disease in greenhouse tomato crops.
Can devastate tomato plantings.

* Spread by water splash.
* The fungus overwinters in plant debris.

Spider mites thrive in dusty conditions;
water-stressed plants are more susceptible to attack.

Content:
## Overview 
 The pathogen infects cucumber, pawpaw , ornamental plants, some weed species etc.
The damaged fruits are susceptible for this disease. 
## Symptoms 
 The fungus infects all parts of plant.
Infected leaves shows small, pinpoint, water soaked spots initially.
As the disease progress the spots enlarge to become necrotic lesions with conspicuous concentric circles, dark margins and light brown centers.
Whereas the fruits exhibit brown, slightly sunken flecks in the beginning but later the lesions become large pitted appearance. 
## Cause 
 Fungus 
## Tips 
 Remove the plant debris and burn them.
Avoid over application of nitrogen fertilizer.
If the disease is severe spray suitable fungicides.
overview:
The pathogen infects cucumber, pawpaw , ornamental plants, some weed species etc.
The damaged fruits are susceptible for this disease.

Content:
## Overview 
 The virus is transmitted by white flies and may cause 100 % yield loss if the plants infect at early stage of crop.
The virus also infect other hosts like common bean, ornamental plants and several weed species. 
## Symptoms 
 The infected leaves become reduced in size, curl upward, appear crumpled and show yellowing of veins and leaf margins.
The internodes become shorter and whole plant appear stunted and bushy.
The whole plant stand erect with only upright growth.
The flowers may not develop and drop off. 
## Cause 
 Virus 
## Tips 
 Grow available resistant varieties.
Transplant only disease and whiteflies free seedlings.
Remove the infected plants and burn them.
Keep the field free from weeds.
Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and control whiteflies.
If the insect infestation is severe spray suitable insecticides.
overview:
The virus is transmitted by white flies and may cause 100 % yield loss if the plants infect at early stage of crop.
The virus also infect other hosts like common bean, ornamental plants and several weed species.

ToMV is a closely related strain of Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV), it enters fields via infected weeds, peppers or potato plants;
the virus may also be transmitted to tomato fields by grasshoppers, small mammals and birds.
